title: Executive One-Pager: Modern SAP AMS in 5 Minutes
hook: This AMS is designed to reduce risk and cost at the same time — without betting the business on big rewrites.
idea: Modern SAP AMS treats SAP as a stable core and manages everything around it with signals, discipline, and automation. The result is predictable operations, safer change, and steadily declining cost-to-serve.

today: High AMS cost with recurring incidents
Changes that feel risky and slow
No clear view where money and effort go
with_this_ams: Recurring problems are eliminated, not normalized
Ownership is explicit across vendors and teams
Cost drivers are visible and controllable

simple_model: Detect issues early using signals, not complaints
Decide fast using evidence and clear ownership
Execute changes safely with gates and rollback
Learn from every issue and automate what repeats
how_it_works.key_principle: If something repeats, the system changes — not the people.

stop_doing: Letting vendors optimize against each other
start_doing: Holding one owner accountable per issue

no_big_bang: No dependency on a single vendor or tool
risk_controls: Clear change gates and rollback rules

year_1: Transparency on real cost drivers appears
year_2: Automation and standard changes reduce run cost

what_success_looks_like: AMS teams focus on improvement, not survival
Leadership can choose where to invest or cut with confidence
final_message: This AMS doesn’t promise zero incidents.
It promises control, learning, and declining cost.
That’s how you run SAP in 2026 and beyond.
design_question: If we ran AMS this way last year, which problems would no longer exist today?
